Title.evidence: INSPIRE 2.0 was a randomized, controlled, parallel, multicenter study

Participants.evidence: Patients with AIS grade A, thoracic (T2-T12), nonpenetrating SCI requiring spine surgery ≤7 days postinjury

Intervention.evidence: randomized (1:1, computer-generated allocation) to undergo NSS implantation or spine surgery alone (control group)

Objective.evidence: we evaluated whether NSS implantation demonstrates probable benefit for safety and neurological recovery in patients with thoracic complete SCI vs standard-of-care spine surgery

Method_Outcome.evidence: proportion of patients with improvement of ≥1 AIS grade at 6 months postsurgery (primary endpoint)

Blinding.evidence: Patients and follow-up International Standards for Neurological Classification of SCI assessors were blinded

Number_Randomised.evidence: Target enrollment was reached (N = 20) with 10 patients randomized and analyzed in each group

Number_Analysed.evidence: 10 patients randomized and analyzed in each group

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 6 months postsurgery, an improvement in the AIS grade was reported in 2 NSS patients (20%; both to AIS C) and 3 control group patients (30%; to AIS B [n = 2] or AIS C [n = 1])

Harms.evidence: No serious or unanticipated adverse device effects were reported
